noun.definition: A large and widespread genus of small mosquitoes (family Culicidae) including several vectors of human disease, notably Aedes aegypti, the principal carrier of yellow fever. Also (in form aedes): a mosquito of this genus (more fully "aedes mosquito").

aedes.origin: Mid 19th century. From scientific Latin Aedes from ancient Greek ἀηδής unpleasant, disagreeable from ἀ- + ἦδος delight, pleasure from the same Indo-European base as sweet.

noun.definition: A simple bomb made and used by unofficial or unauthorized forces.

adjective.definition: Of or characteristic of the Mediterranean Sea, the countries bordering it, or their inhabitants.

noun.definition: The Mediterranean Sea or the countries bordering it.
noun.example: a permanent American naval presence in the Mediterranean

noun.definition: A native of a Mediterranean country.
noun.example: an admiring audience of Mediterraneans

mediterranean.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin mediterraneus ‘inland’ (from medius ‘middle’ + terra ‘land’) + -an.

noun.definition: Complete lack of inhibition or restraint.
noun.example: she sings and sways with total abandon

verb.definition: Cease to support or look after (someone); desert.
verb.example: her natural mother had abandoned her at an early age

verb.definition: Give up completely (a practice or a course of action)
verb.example: he had clearly abandoned all pretence of trying to succeed

verb.definition: Allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse)
verb.example: they abandoned themselves to despair

abandon.origin: Late Middle English from Old French abandoner, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + bandon ‘control’ (related to ban). The original sense was ‘bring under control’, later ‘give in to the control of, surrender to’ (abandon (sense 3 of the verb)).

verb.definition: Take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
verb.example: the millionaire who disappeared may have been abducted

verb.definition: (of a muscle) move (a limb or part) away from the midline of the body or from another part.
verb.example: the posterior rectus muscle, which abducts the eye

abduct.origin: Early 17th century from Latin abduct- ‘led away’, from the verb abducere, from ab- ‘away, from’ + ducere ‘to lead’.

abductor.example: Police rescued an abducted boy of comilla district and arrested the abductor from haji eidgah math area at dimla upazila in nilphamari on saturday, police sources said.

noun.definition: A person who abducts another person.
noun.example: she endured a two-hour ordeal at the hands of her abductors

abductor.origin: Early 17th century (as a term in anatomy): modern Latin (see abduct).

ablaze.example: A housewife succumbed to her injuries today four days after she set herself ablaze as she was tortured by her husband allegedly for dowry.

verb.definition: Exist in large numbers or amounts.
verb.example: rumours of a further scandal abound

abound.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘overflow, be abundant’): from Old French abunder, from Latin abundare ‘overflow’, from ab- ‘from’ + undare ‘surge’ (from unda ‘a wave’).

verb.definition: Take in or soak up (energy or a liquid or other substance) by chemical or physical action.
verb.example: buildings can be designed to absorb and retain heat

verb.definition: Take up the attention of (someone); interest greatly.
verb.example: she sat in an armchair, absorbed in a book

absorb.origin: Late Middle English from Latin absorbere, from ab- ‘from’ + sorbere ‘suck in’.

noun.definition: An absurd state of affairs.
noun.example: the incidents that followed bordered on the absurd

absurd.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin absurdus ‘out of tune’, hence ‘irrational’; related to surdus ‘deaf, dull’.

adjective.definition: Existing or available in large quantities; plentiful.
adjective.example: there was abundant evidence to support the theory

abundant.origin: Late Middle English from Latin abundant- ‘abounding’, from the verb abundare (see abound).

adverb.example: the plant grows abundantly in the wild

abysmal.example: "I think over the last few months the behaviour has been abysmal in international cricket," arthur, who is currently pakistan's head coach, said.

adjective.example: the quality of her work is abysmal
waterfalls that plunge into abysmal depths

abysmal.origin: Mid 17th century (used literally as in abysmal (sense 2)): from abysm. abysmal (sense 1) dates from the early 19th century.

noun.definition: A person who helps another commit a crime.
noun.example: an accomplice in the murder

accomplice.origin: Mid 16th century alteration (probably by association with accompany) of Middle English complice ‘an associate’, via Old French from late Latin complex, complic- ‘allied’, from com- ‘together’ + the root of plicare ‘to fold’.

verb.definition: Achieve or complete successfully.
verb.example: the planes accomplished their mission

accomplish.origin: Late Middle English from Old French acompliss-, lengthened stem of acomplir, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ + complere ‘to complete’.

noun.definition: An official agreement or treaty.
noun.example: opposition groups refused to sign the accord

verb.definition: Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition)
verb.example: the powers accorded to the head of state

verb.definition: (of a concept or fact) be harmonious or consistent with.
verb.example: his views accorded well with those of Merivale

accord.origin: Old English, from Old French acorder ‘reconcile, be of one mind’, from Latin ad- ‘to’ + cor, cord- ‘heart’; influenced by concord.

noun.definition: A report or description of an event or experience.
noun.example: a detailed account of what has been achieved

noun.definition: A record or statement of financial expenditure and receipts relating to a particular period or purpose.
noun.example: the barman was doing his accounts

noun.definition: An arrangement by which a body holds funds on behalf of a client or supplies goods or services to them on credit.
noun.example: a bank account

noun.definition: An arrangement by which a user is given personalized access to a computer, website, or application, typically by entering a username and password.
noun.example: we've reset your password to prevent others from accessing your account

noun.definition: Importance.
noun.example: money was of no account to her

verb.definition: Consider or regard in a specified way.
verb.example: her visit could not be accounted a success

verb.definition: Give or receive an account for money received.
verb.example: after 1292 he accounted to the Westminster exchequer

account.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘counting’, ‘to count’): from Old French acont (noun), aconter (verb), based on conter ‘to count’.

verb.definition: Charge (someone) with an offence or crime.
verb.example: he was accused of murdering his wife's lover

accuse.origin: Middle English from Old French acuser, from Latin accusare ‘call to account’, from ad- ‘towards’ + causa ‘reason, motive, lawsuit’.

verb.definition: Make someone or something accept (something) as normal or usual.
verb.example: I accustomed my eyes to the lenses

accustom.origin: Late Middle English from Old French acostumer, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + costume ‘custom’.

noun.definition: A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
noun.example: the ace of diamonds

noun.definition: A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
noun.example: a motorcycle ace

noun.definition: (in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
noun.example: Nadal banged down eight aces in the set

verb.definition: (in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
verb.example: he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph

verb.definition: Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
verb.example: I aced my grammar test

ace.origin: Middle English (denoting the ‘one’ on dice): via Old French from Latin as ‘unity, a unit’.

adjective.definition: (of a person) having no sexual feelings or desires; asexual.
adjective.example: I didn't realize that I was ace for a long time

noun.definition: A person who has no sexual feelings or desires.
noun.example: both asexual, they have managed to connect with other aces offline

ace.origin: Early 21st century abbreviation of asexual, with alteration of spelling on the model of ace.

noun.definition: A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
noun.example: the ache in her head worsened

verb.definition: Suffer from a continuous dull pain.
verb.example: my legs ached from the previous day's exercise

ache.origin: Old English æce (noun), acan (verb). In Middle English and early modern English the noun was spelled atche and rhymed with ‘batch’ and the verb was spelled and pronounced as it is today. The noun began to be pronounced like the verb around 1700. The modern spelling is largely due to Dr Johnson, who mistakenly assumed its derivation to be from Greek akhos ‘pain’.

verb.definition: Buy or obtain (an asset or object) for oneself.
verb.example: I managed to acquire all the books I needed

verb.definition: Learn or develop (a skill, habit, or quality)
verb.example: you must acquire the rudiments of Greek

acquire.origin: Late Middle English acquere, from Old French aquerre, based on Latin acquirere ‘get in addition’, from ad- ‘to’ + quaerere ‘seek’. The English spelling was modified (c1600) by association with the Latin word.

noun.definition: An asset or object bought or obtained, typically by a library or museum.
noun.example: the legacy will be used for new acquisitions

noun.definition: The learning or developing of a skill, habit, or quality.
noun.example: the acquisition of management skills

acquisition.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘act of acquiring something’): from Latin acquisitio(n-), from the verb acquirere (see acquire).

adjective.definition: Temporarily doing the duties of another person.

noun.definition: The art or occupation of performing fictional roles in plays, films, or television.
noun.example: she studied acting in New York

adjective.definition: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
adjective.example: he is adamant that he is not going to resign

noun.definition: A legendary rock or mineral to which many properties were attributed, formerly associated with diamond or lodestone.
noun.example: As for the magical metal, asiceton, it sounds like adamant.

adamant.origin: Old English (as a noun), from Old French adamaunt-, via Latin from Greek adamas, adamant-, ‘untameable, invincible’ (later used to denote the hardest metal or stone, hence diamond), from a- ‘not’ + daman ‘to tame’. The phrase to be adamant dates from the 1930s, although adjectival use had been implied in such collocations as ‘an adamant heart’ since the 16th century.

noun.definition: The action or process of adapting or being adapted.
noun.example: the adaptation of teaching strategy to meet students' needs

adaptation.origin: Early 17th century from French, from late Latin adaptatio(n-), from Latin adaptare (see adapt).

noun.definition: An item of additional material added at the end of a book or other publication.
The radial distance from the pitch circle of a cogwheel or wormwheel to the crests of the teeth or ridges.

addendum.origin: Late 17th century Latin, ‘that which is to be added’, gerundive of addere (see add).

adjective.definition: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.
adjective.example: this office is perfectly adequate for my needs

adequate.origin: Early 17th century from Latin adaequatus ‘made equal to’, past participle of the verb adaequare, from ad- ‘to’ + aequus ‘equal’.

verb.definition: Stick fast to (a surface or substance)
verb.example: paint won't adhere well to a greasy surface

verb.definition: Believe in and follow the practices of.
verb.example: I do not adhere to any organized religion

adhere.origin: Late 15th century from Latin adhaerere, from ad- ‘to’ + haerere ‘to stick’.

verb.definition: Break off (a meeting, legal case, or game) with the intention of resuming it later.
verb.example: the meeting was adjourned until December 4

adjourn.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘summon someone to appear on a particular day’): from Old French ajorner, from the phrase a jorn (nome) ‘to an (appointed) day’.

verb.definition: Confess to be true or to be the case.
verb.example: the Home Office finally admitted that several prisoners had been injured

verb.definition: Allow (someone) to enter a place.
verb.example: old-age pensioners are admitted free to the museum

verb.definition: Accept as valid.
verb.example: the courts can refuse to admit police evidence which has been illegally obtained

verb.definition: Allow the possibility of.
verb.example: the need to inform him was too urgent to admit of further delay

admit.origin: Late Middle English from Latin admittere, from ad- ‘to’ + mittere ‘send’.
